article-meta.issue-title: Special Issue on New Methods for the Study of Written Communication

body.p: We are pleased to announce the following 2012 Written Communication awards.

sec.title: 2012 John R. Hayes Award for Excellence in Research
sec.p: Allan McDougall, University of West Ontario, Canada
Glendon R. Tait, Dalhousie University, Canada
Lorelei Lingard, University of Toronto, Canada
“Creating Discursive Order at the End of Life: The Role of Genres in Palliative Care Settings.” Written Communication, 29, 111-141.

The Awards Committee, consisting of Davida Charney (chair), Sarah McCarthey, Nancy Penrose, and Lynda Walsh, provided the following citation:
This year’s nominated articles extended our understanding of the cognitive processes underlying writing skills, the acquisition of discipline-specific argument strategies, and the co-construction of discourse in real-world settings. Their data sources ranged from keystrokes to extended genres. Like its fellow nominees, the winning article is exemplary in its grounding in previous research and rigorous in its application of its chosen methods but it stands out in its implications for practice and future research.
“Creating Discursive Order at the End of Life: The Role of Genres in Palliative Care Settings,” by Catherine Schryer, Allan McDougall, Glendon R. Tait, and Lorelei Lingard, studies an emerging genre in medical discourse in Canada, the patient legacy document which is co-created by a medical resident and a dying patient.
Previous research shows that the most common genres of medical discourse limit patient agency and frame death as a medical failure. In contrast, the patient legacy document increases a patient’s sense of dignity and purpose. In this study, Schryer et al. hypothesize that the therapeutic benefit of the document stems from the patient’s increased rhetorical agency as he or she reflects on and interprets their life experiences. The authors contrast this personal meaning-making with the other-centered discourse of related genres such as eulogies and medical intake interviews. Schryer et al. analyze the interview protocol itself as well as twelve cases. They pay close attention to linguistic features as they trace the discursive links by which rhetorical agency is created—for example, how the patients pick up on verb forms in the interview questions as they shape an interpretation of their own memories.
An important goal of writing research is to foster improved communication not only in schools and workplaces but also in the world. This study has the potential to improve doctor-patient communication on several levels. First, the research team, which included specialists in rhetoric and professional communication, linguistics, medical training, and psychiatry, has the ethos to disseminate the findings in real-world settings. Second, the quality of exposition of the article and the universality of its topic make this a study that will attract attention from a wider readership. Finally, the study has promising implications for future research exploring the effect of this kind of communication on the medical community itself. “The article stands as an eloquent example of how rhetorical genre studies can yield valuable academic insights while respecting the integrity of human expression.” Thank you for the opportunity to read again and to evaluate this fine set of articles.
The authors have chosen to donate the $1,000 award to a hospice.

sec.title: 2012 Best New Scholar Award
sec.p: Bethany Davila, University of New Mexico, Albuquerque; USA
“Indexicality and ‘Standard’ Edited American English: Examining the Link Between Conceptions of Standardness and Perceived Authorial Identity.” Written Communication, 29, 180-207.
Congratulations to Prof. Davila on her Award. This article was also nominated for the John R. Hayes Award, so her work has been very well received.

sec.title: 2012 Editor’s Citation for Excellence in Reviewing
sec.p: Lynda Walsh, University of Nevada, Reno; USA

The Editor and Editorial Board wish to thank Prof. Walsh for her insightful, detailed, useful, and timely reviews; for her willingness to take on extra tasks for the journal (sometimes with little warning); and for her insights and advice to the Editor.
